conclusion: Understanding the ion implantation process in chip manufacturing.
Ions are accelerated from the ion source and enter the velocity selector horizontally.
The velocity selector has both electric and magnetic fields with electric field directed vertically upwards and magnetic field directed outward perpendicular to the paper.
Electric force on the ion is qE (upward), and magnetic force is qvB (downward). For the ion to pass through straightly, these forces should balance each other: qE = qvB.
Solving for velocity v: v = E / B.
Ions exit the velocity selector with a specific velocity v = E / B.
Ions enter the magnetic analyzer, which is a quarter-circular ring with inner radius R1 and outer radius R2.
The magnetic field in the analyzer is B, directed outward.
In the magnetic field, ions follow a circular path with centripetal force provided by magnetic force: qvB = m v^2 / R.
Solving for R: R = mv / qB.
Substituting v = E / B into R: R = mE / qB^2.
Only ions with a specific charge-to-mass ratio (q/m) will follow the desired path with radius R between R1 and R2.
Ions enter the deflection system, which also has electric and magnetic fields.
The electric field in the deflection system is directed outward perpendicular to the paper, and the magnetic field is directed the same way as before.
In the deflection system, the total force is F_total = qE + qvB = q(E + vB).
Deflection angles are small, allowing approximations like sinα ≈ tanα ≈ α and cosα ≈ 1 - (1/2)α².
Ions are implanted into a wafer lying in the horizontal plane with a coordinate system having point O as the origin.
Need to find out how the deflection system affects the position where the ions hit the wafer.
Deflection system is a cube with side length L, and the bottom of the cube is parallel to the wafer, at a distance L from it.
When no fields are applied, ions hit point O on the wafer.
